body:

`netlib` from head was installed into the `virtualenv` as well with `pip install -e git+https://github.com/mitmproxy/netlib#egg=netlib`

Excellent report, thanks. I'll take a look soon, although it may take a bit
as I'm on holiday - please bear with me. :-)

Cheers,
Max

Maximilian Hils notifications@github.com wrote:

> Excellent report, thanks. I'll take a look soon, although it may take a bit
> as I'm on holiday - please bear with me. :-)

Stop logging in then! :-p

Fixed. 

@Jamie-Landeg-Jones: All depends on the weather :wink: 

Cheers,
Max

Thanks a lot, all working now. 

As a side note, the trace was hard to get as it was getting cleared from the screen so all the notes about submitting a bug were silently disappearing.  I had to create a putty log file to be able to capture the info.  

It would also be useful if the event log and or errors could be redirected to a file, at least that was the option I was looking for after the crash!

Matt Hoyle notifications@github.com wrote:

> It would also be useful if the event log and or errors could be redirected to a file, at least that was the option I was looking for after the crash!

On unix?

try the 'script' command!

Thanks for the feedback. What exactly do you mean by "the trace was hard to get as it was getting cleared from the screen"? If the event log is open, you can press tab to switch to it and then use the arrow keys to navigate. Cheers, Max

Max, `mitmproxy` had crashed so the request and event logs are not available any more to see what requests have happened or what may have lead up to the issue.  When the screen is cleared at the crash (I assume it's curses based?) I am returned to my shell but the final `mitmproxy` stack trace is not printed, it is being cleared as well.   

Thanks Jamie, that captures it too but it's a bit awkward to have to run it like that all the time in case of a crash.

Screw curses :-) I do get the full tracaback on the console (Ubuntu 12.04, default Terminal), so I'm not sure what causes the issue you're seeing.

Which OS are you on? Which Terminal application are you using?

Cheers,
Max

rename.from: mitmproxy crash on custom response in script
rename.to: mitmproxy stack trace cleared from console

body:
Putty 0.63 xterm to Debian Wheezy (3.2.54-2).

I'll run `mitmproxy` directly on the box and see if I get a different result or not on the next crash.

Another thread where I didn't get all the updates (though I did get some.....)

Sorry I missed that the first time, but I too don't get the screen clearing on me... I'm wondering if it's to do with evil use of smcup/rmcup? (The xterm 'alternate screen' (mis)-feature - Though to be fair, the feature is fine, it's just the braindead way people have used it that gets me deleting any trace of it that crops up!)

I'll have a fiddle and see if this is the issue, and if I can reproduce it.
The following 2 links may provide some insight:

http://chenyufei.info/blog/2011-12-15/prevent-vim-less-clear-screen-on-exit/

https://blogs.oracle.com/samf/entry/smcup_rmcup_hate

Thanks for that, looks like it. `mitmproxy` is sending something close to an `xterm-color` `smcup` at the start and `rmcup` after the stack trace. Funnily enough that happens with putty set to `xterm` and both ends happily deal with it!

```
$ tail -c 256 mitmproxy_out.log.20140901-170702 | less
```

.

```
<snipped stacktrace>
mitmproxy has crashed!
Please lodge a bug report at: https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy
Shutting down... 
ESC[?1002lESC[?1000lESC[0;39;49m^OESC[?47lESC8ESC[?25h
Script done on Mon 01 Sep 2014 17:31:52 BST
```

It's the `ESC[?47lESC8` bit but there's a slightly different prefix in my definition. 

```
$ infocmp xterm-color | grep mcup
        ri=\EM, rmacs=^O, rmcup=\E[2J\E[?47l\E8, rmir=\E[4l,
        smcup=\E7\E[?47h, smir=\E[4h, smkx=\E[?1h\E=, smso=\E[7m,
```

It's not even close the values in `xterm`

```
$ infocmp xterm | grep mcup
        rin=\E[%p1%dT, rmacs=\E(B, rmam=\E[?7l, rmcup=\E[?1049l,
        sgr0=\E(B\E[m, smacs=\E(0, smam=\E[?7h, smcup=\E[?1049h,
```

The equivelant tmux/screen option from those links in Putty is "Disable switching to alternate terminal screen" (Putty Session options > Terminal > Features). That does work around the problem but I'd prefer to leave that if possible as I'm in the "I like the screen clearing" camp =)

I'll have a poke through `urwid` and see if the terminal finalisation stuff can be dealt with before the strack trace is printed

So it looks like Putty supports both the `\E[?1049l` and `\E[?47l` sequences to switch back from the alternate buffer. Some more detail on them: http://invisible-island.net/xterm/xterm.faq.html#xterm_tite

The output stays on the linux console in Debian as the termtype of `linux` doesn't have smcup/rmcup so I would assume that terminal also doesn't deal with them and they are ignored. 

Of note, `urwid` doesn't respect the current terminal type or local termcap and just uses the sequences it has coded in [`urwid/escape.py`](https://github.com/wardi/urwid/blob/master/urwid/escape.py#L402-L403).  Someone had raised the issue https://github.com/wardi/urwid/issues/33 but that was hacked around instead of resolved. 

These are the sequences `urwid` uses:

```
SWITCH_TO_ALTERNATE_BUFFER = ESC+"7"+ESC+"[?47h"
RESTORE_NORMAL_BUFFER = ESC+"[?47l"+ESC+"8"
```

The additional escape 7 saves the cursor position and escape 8, restores it. 

`urwid` adds in the extra `clear` (`ESC[?2J`) via a call to `Screen.clear` at the top of the `raw_display.Screen.stop` method...

issue.title: Add urwid stop prior to exception output so stack trace is not cleared

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
mitmproxy outputs into the "alternate" buffer via `urwid`
`urwid` clears the screen and reverts to the original buffer in it's final cleanup after a stack trace is printed. https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/330

This change finalises `urwid` before the stack trace.

body:
The corresponding PR has been merged, so I'll close this issue.

Thanks again!

Thanks Max. I wasn't sure how to inject an exception in Python so I added an E key for the testing. https://github.com/deployable/mitmproxy/commit/7b2d498acf6d24b05fb54bb16d1775335e57d15f
That didn't seem like it should be in the commit though.
